Section 11 (1) read with Section 11(2)(a) of the SEBI Act, 1992
Expiries of all equity derivatives contracts of an exchange will be uniformly limited to either Tuesday or Thursday.
Every exchange will continue to be allowed one weekly benchmark index options contract on their chosen day (Tuesday or Thursday).

key_clauses: Norms for Internal Audit Mechanism and composition of the Audit Committee of Market Infrastructure Institutions
MIIs shall operate in an efficient and transparent manner, be accountable for their actions, maintain highest standards of governance and risk management
Internal audit helps to identify, assess, and mitigate risks that could impact the MII’s operations, efficiency, financial stability
MIIs being corporate entities governed by the provisions of Companies Act, 2013 are required to conduct Internal Audit
Governing boards of the MIIs are required to provide for three lines of defense of which the third line of defense comprises the Internal Audit Function
Every MII shall conduct internal audit of all functions and activities of the MII at least once in a Financial Year
Internal auditor of an MII shall report only to the Audit Committee of the MII
The Audit Committee of the MII shall not consist of any Executive Director (including the Managing Director) of the MII

The auditors of the MII and the Key Management Personnel (KMPs) shall have a right to be heard in the meetings of the Audit Committee when it considers the auditor‘s report but shall not have the right to vote
This circular is issued in exercise of the powers conferred under section 11(1) of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act 1992

The observations of the internal auditor shall be sent to the respective Head of Departments (HoDs) for their comments in a time bound manner
The internal auditor after incorporating comments of the HoDs shall share the final report with the Audit Committee in a time bound manner
The various timelines for internal audit shall be prescribed by the Audit Committee of the MII

Make necessary amendments to the relevant byelaws, rules and regulations, wherever required, for the implementation of the above

key_clauses: Review of provisions pertaining to Electronic Book Provider (EBP) platform to increase its efficacy and utility

Issues of debt securities and NCRPS as per SEBI NCS Regulations, 2021 and municipal debt securities as per SEBI (Issue and Listing of Municipal Debt Securities) Regulations, 2015 shall be made through the EBP platform if it is a single issue of Rs. 20 crore or more.

An issuer may choose to access EBP platform for private placement of securitised debt instruments or security receipts or CPs or CDs, and issuers constituted as REITs, SM REITs and InvITs may also access the EBP platform for private placement of units of REITs, SM REITs and InvITs.
Issuers of debt securities, NCRPS and municipal debt securities on private placement basis of issue size less than Rs. 20 crore may also choose to access the EBP platform for such issuances.
The Issuer shall provide the Placement Memorandum and term sheet to the EBP at least two working days prior to the issue opening date.
The green shoe portion shall not exceed five times the base issue size.
If there are two or more bids at cut-off coupon/ price/ spread, then allotment shall be done on ‘pro-rata’ basis.
The quantum of allocation(s) to the anchor investor(s) shall be at the discretion of the issuer, subject to total allocation to the anchor(s) not exceeding the base issue size.
Anchor Portion (%) of base size for AAA/ AA+/AA/AA- rating is Not exceeding 30%
Anchor Portion (%) of base size for A+/A- rating is Not exceeding 40%
actionable_items: Issuers to comply with revised EBP platform provisions for private placement of securities.
Issuers to provide Placement Memorandum and term sheet to EBP at least two working days prior to issue opening.
EBPs shall ensure that details regarding the issuance is updated on its website by end of T-day for issues closing upto 1 p.m. on T-day and by 1 p.m. on T+1 day for the remaining issues.
Issuers to disclose details of anchor investor(s) and the corresponding quantum allocated, to the EBP, along with the Placement Memorandum and the term sheet.
Anchor investors shall provide electronic confirmation on the EBP platform of their participation by T-1 day.

Issuer shall ensure prior receipt of in-principle approval from the stock exchange(s) where it wishes to list its proposed debt issuance/ securities, prior to the date of providing the Placement Memorandum and term sheet to the EBP(s).

key_clauses: Facilitation to SEBI registered Stock Brokers to undertake securities market related activities in GIFT-IFSC under a Separate Business Unit (SBU)
Requirement of obtaining specific approval from SEBI is done away with.
Stock brokers permitted to undertake activities in GIFT-IFSC under a Separate Business Unit (SBU).
Existing practice of carrying out activities in GIFT-IFSC through a subsidiary is also allowed.

Policy, eligibility criteria, risk management, investor grievances, inspection, enforcement, claims etc. for SBU in GIFT-IFSC would be specified under the regulatory framework issued by the concerned regulatory authority.
Securities market related activities of the SBU in GIFT-IFSC are segregated and ring-fenced from the Indian securities market related activities.
SBU in GIFT-IFSC shall be exclusively engaged in providing securities market related activities as permitted by the IFSCA.
Stock brokers shall prepare and maintain a separate account for the SBU on arms-length basis.
Net worth of the SBU shall be kept segregated from the net worth of the stock broker in the Indian securities market.
Grievance Redressal Mechanism and Investor Protection Fund (IPF) of the stock exchanges and SCORES shall not be available for investors availing the services of the SBU.
actionable_items: Stock brokers proposing to undertake securities market related activities in GIFT-IFSC are permitted to do so under a Separate Business Unit (SBU).
Stock brokers shall ensure segregation and ring-fencing of SBU activities from Indian securities market activities.
Stock brokers shall maintain a separate account for the SBU on arms-length basis.
Stock brokers shall ensure net worth criteria are satisfied after excluding the account of the SBU.
Stock brokers who have already floated a subsidiary/JV have the option to dismantle it and carry out services under an SBU.
Comply with regulatory framework issued by the concerned regulatory authority for SBU in GIFT-IFSC.
Ensure activities carried out by the SBU are permitted by the IFSCA.

key_clauses: Clarifications to Cybersecurity and Cyber Resilience Framework (CSCRF) for SEBI Regulated Entities (REs)
Category of REs shall be decided at the beginning of the financial year based on the data of the previous financial year.
Once the category of RE is decided, RE shall remain in the same category throughout the financial year irrespective of any changes in the parameters during the financial year.
DPs having clients less than 100 shall be exempted from the requirement of SOC services or on-boarding to Market-SOC (M-SOC).
IAs not registered with SEBI in other capacities shall be exempted from provisions of CSCRF.
RAs not registered with SEBI in any other capacity shall be exempted from the CSCRF framework.
KRAs shall be re-categorised from MIIs to Qualified REs.
Portfolio Managers who fall under self-certification REs category and have less than 100 clients shall be exempted from the requirement of mandatory Market-SOC (M-SOC).
Implementation of a dedicated Hardware Security Module (HSM) shall be made mandatory for MIIs and Qualified REs.

actionable_items: Stock Brokers, Depository Participants, KRAs, Portfolio Managers, Investment Advisers (IAs)/ Research Analysts (RAs), Merchant Bankers (MBs), AIFs/ VCFs and Registrars to an Issue / Share Transfer Agents shall take necessary action for implementation of the circular.
